isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Service (1995 through 1999) - SECTION 7: VIBRATION DAMPER, CRANKSHAFT, MAIN BEARINGS, FLYWHEEL AND CRANKCASE - CRANKCASE (RECONDITIONING) - INSPECTION AND REPAIR

note.para: Threaded holes with damaged threads may be salvaged with the use of a thread insert.

step1.para:
Inspect the crankcase deck for flatness using a straightedge ( OEM1293) and feeler gauge. Use the checking pattern shown in Figure 7.76
. If a 0.076mm (0.003 in.) feeler gauge can pass, the crankcase must be replaced.

note.para: DO NOT RESURFACE THE CRANKCASE. SURFACE DEFECTS BEYOND THOSE LISTED IN STEP ONE, ABOVE, ARE NOT CORRECTABLE. REPLACE THE CRANKCASE.

step1.para:
Visually inspect the piston oil jet tubes for blockage as follows ( Figure 7.77
):

step2.para: Shine a light source under the small orifice in the tube end which protrudes into the crankcase from its insertion point in the bearing saddle.
Position your eye to align with the large orifice of the piston cooling jet. If the light source is visible, the jet tube is clear and requires no further service.
If the light source is not visible, the piston cooling jet tube is blocked. Clean the tube to remove any blockage.

figure.caption: Figure 7.77 Inspecting Piston Oil Jet Tubes

step1.para:
Clean piston oil jet tube blockage as follows: Refer to
Figure 7.78
.

step2.para: Run an appropriately sized wire or torch tip cleaner through the tube orifice to remove blockage.
Using filtered compressed air, blow loosened debris out from the jet tube orifice.
Reinspect piston cooling jet tube using a light source as previously described.

note.para: Do not remove piston cooling jet tubes unless they are damaged or cannot pass the visual inspection after cleaning.

caution.para: ALWAYS WEAR SAFETY GLASSES WHEN USING COMPRESSED AIR.
